newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian dollar opens weaker in light trading.
newsitem.headline: Canadian dollar opens weaker in light trading.

text.p: * Canada's dollar opened weaker at C$1.3786 (US$0.7253) in light trading on Friday as investors sold the unit ahead of U.S. economic data due to be released today, traders said.
* They said the Canada dollar also weakened on the back of a move by the Bank of England to raise interest rates by 25 basis points.
Smaller-than-expected numbers would point to a slowdown in the U.S. economy, while higher numbers would help the U.S. Federal Reserve press its case for an interest rate hike to ward off inflation.
The Federal Open Market Committee could spike interest rates at its next July 1-2 meeting.

"People are selling Canada (dollar) before the payrolls numbers. There is still a predisposition in this market to thinking that the Americans are going to get a hot number, which would point to Fed activity in July," said Reid Farrill, corporate foreign exchange adviser for CIBC Wood Gundy.

Canada released unemployment data earlier this morning showing a small drop in the unemployment rate to 9.5 percent in May from 9.6 percent in April. The decrease was in line with a Reuters survey of economists forecast.
Statistics Canada also reported that full-time employment rose by 61,300 in May, compared with an increase of 33,000 in April.
Traders, however, said the numbers would not be enough to fuel a Canada dollar rally on its own.
"The Canadian dollar can't really do much ahead of the U.S. data," one trader said.
Traders said the Canada dollar also weakened on the back of a move by the Bank of England to raise interest rates by 25 basis points.

The bank said that recent economic data had not changed the view that it took in its inflation report last month that "on present evidence," there is likely to be a need for some further moderate tightening of policy in the months ahead.
On the crosses, the Canadian dollar was flat at 83.94 yen from Thursday's close and increased to 1.2609 marks from Thursday's 1.2544 marks.
